View pregnancy details
No noticeable changes yet as this week is still part of the menstrual cycle.
Ovulation occurs and the body prepares for fertilization.
Fertilization may happen, and the zygote begins forming.
Missed menstrual period; possible mild cramping and spotting as the embryo implants.
Early signs of pregnancy like nausea, fatigue, and breast tenderness may appear.
Possible increase in nausea, heightened sense of smell, and frequent urination.
Morning sickness may continue; the embryo is about the size of a blueberry.
The embryo starts to form facial features; morning sickness and fatigue may persist.
The fetus may begin to move, though it\'s too early to feel it; hormonal changes continue.
The risk of miscarriage decreases; the fetus\'s critical development is underway.
The fetus is almost fully formed; the partner might notice a slight growth in belly size.
The risk of miscarriage drops significantly; energy levels may start to rise.
The first trimester ends; some symptoms may lessen as the second trimester begins.
Expect a growing appetite and possible appearance of a baby bump.
Baby’s skeleton begins to ossify, and the pregnant partner may feel more energetic.
The baby\'s eyes and ears are moving into place; the partner might start feeling fluttering sensations.
Increased body fluids could lead to stuffiness and nosebleeds.
The baby is active, and the pregnant partner may start to feel movement.
Some partners start to feel Braxton Hicks contractions as the body prepares for labor.
The halfway point; an ultrasound may reveal the baby’s sex.
The baby\'s taste buds are developing, and movements become more noticeable.
The baby is sleeping in cycles; the pregnant partner may notice swelling in the ankles and feet.
The baby\'s hearing is developing, they may respond to sounds.
The baby\'s lungs are developing; a glucose screening test may be scheduled to check for gestational diabetes.
The baby may start to respond to familiar voices.
The baby’s eyes begin to open; the pregnant partner may experience backaches and sleep disturbances.
The end of the second trimester; the baby\'s brain activity is increasing.
The third trimester begins; the baby continues to put on weight and grow in length.
The baby\'s muscles and lungs are continuing to mature.
The baby may move to a head-down position in preparation for birth.
The baby\'s rapid growth continues; the partner\'s navel may protrude.
The baby\'s bones are fully formed, but still soft.
The baby\'s brain is developing; the pregnant partner may notice a decrease in fetal movements as the baby grows larger.
The baby begins to develop their own immune system.
The baby\'s kidneys are fully developed, and the liver can process some waste products.
The baby gains about an ounce a day; the pregnant partner may feel more uncomfortable as the due date approaches.
The baby is considered early-term; they continue to build fat layers.
At week 38, the baby is considered full-term. The pregnant person might experience more Braxton Hicks contractions as the body prepares for labor.
During week 39, the pregnant person might notice the baby dropping lower into the pelvis. This is called "lightening" and indicates preparation for birth.
The due date arrives in week 40. If there are no signs of labor, the healthcare provider may discuss options like waiting for natural labor or scheduling an induction.
What to expect: Week %1$s
